lessons.title: Welcome to OOP!
masteryOutcomes: Understand the course main topics and grading

lessons.title: What is OOP and why do we need it?
masteryOutcomes: Understand why different programming paradigms exist.
Identify Object-Oriented Programming as a paradigm
Understand why Object-Oriented Programming is used based on real-world examples

lessons.title: Objects = data + behavior
masteryOutcomes: Identify an object as an entity that combines data attributes (state) and behavior (actions).
Distinguish between the state and behavior of real-world objects.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Cafe order ticket
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice identifying objects, their state (data), and behavior (actions) by modeling a simple cafe order in code and comments. Output: A small script that describes a cafe order object with example data and prints out its state and a description of its behavior.

lessons.title: Classes and instances
masteryOutcomes: Identify a class as a blueprint that defines shared structure and behavior.
Understand what a class instance is and that multiple instances can be created from the same class.
Recognize basic CaptialCase convention for Class names.

lessons.title: Object identity vs equality
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish between two variables pointing to the same object and two objects having the same value.
Explain why identity vs equality matters when working with object state.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Library book tracker
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Reinforce the idea of classes as blueprints and instances as concrete objects by modeling books in a library system. Output: A script that defines a Book class, creates multiple Book instances, and prints details showing that each instance has its own data.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Identity vs equality demo
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Deepen understanding of object identity versus equality by experimenting with variables that share references and variables that only share values. Output: A script that compares several objects using == and is, prints the results, and explains via printed messages which objects are identical and which are only equal in value.

lessons.title: Mutable vs immutable, why it matters
masteryOutcomes: Understand the necessity of mutability & immutability objects.
Identify common mutable types and common immutable types in Python.

lessons.title: Class-level basics: attributes & methods
masteryOutcomes: Identify a class attribute as shared data stored on the class.
Recognize a class method as behavior called on the class .

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Shopping cart mutability
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice distinguishing between mutable and immutable objects by simulating a shopping cart where items can be added, removed, and compared. Output: A script that simulates adding and removing items from a cart, showing how changes to mutable objects affect references while immutable values remain unchanged.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Game settings manager
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply class attributes and methods to manage shared game settings separate from per-player data. Output: A script that defines a GameSettings class with shared settings and methods, then demonstrates how changing a class attribute affects multiple player objects.

lessons.title: Quick detour: built-in modules
masteryOutcomes: Recognize a module as a collection of related Python code.
Use an import statement to access basic code from a built-in module.

lessons.title: Objects in action
masteryOutcomes: Recognize that calling Random() with parenthesis, creates an object (instance) from a class.
Understand that the object's actions are called and use methods on a Random object to trigger behavior and produce data.
Distinguish between the object itself, its methods, and the data produced by those methods.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Dice roller
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use a built-in module and a Random object to simulate dice rolls and clearly separate the object, its methods, and the data they return. Output: A script that imports the random module, creates a Random object, and prints several simulated dice rolls.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Password helper - Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice importing built-in modules and using their objects and methods to generate simple random password suggestions. Output: A script that uses functions and/or objects from built-in modules (such as random and string) to print a few randomly generated password suggestions.

lessons.title: Creating your first class
masteryOutcomes: Ability to define a minimal Python class using the class keyword without providing an __init__ method.
Ability to create objects from a basic class, inspect it's type, and assign attributes to those objects after instantiation.
Ability to diffrentiate between class definition and instantiation, prefereably using comments in code

lessons.title: Creating multiple objects from one class
masteryOutcomes: Understand that each object created from a class maintains its own independent set of attribute values.
Ability to create a class from scratch, and then instantiate two more objects from it and assign different attribute values.
Ability to seperate between the variable name (the one that holds the instance) and the attributes inside an instance.

lessons.title: Methods: the role of self
masteryOutcomes: Ability to define a class method with self as the first parameter (without exploring its meaning yet).
Understand `self` as a reference to the current object, used by methods to access its data and behavior.
Create an object and call its instance methods using dot notation to trigger behavior.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Cafe customer
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice defining a minimal class, creating multiple objects from it, assigning attributes after instantiation, and calling simple methods that use self. Output: A short script that creates several cafe customer objects, assigns them names and favorite drinks, and prints personalized messages for each customer.

lessons.title: Self param, and methods that use attributes
masteryOutcomes: Understand the meaning of the self param
Ability to write an instance method that accesses attributes via self to produce output such as printing a stored name.
Capability to reason about how changes to object attributes affect the behavior of instance methods that reference those attributes.

lessons.title: Challenge I
masteryOutcomes: Ability to compose a small Python program that defines and uses classes and objects, representing real life entities.
Capability to trace how objects created from different classes interact through method calls and attribute access in a simple application.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Music playlist
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Reinforce using self inside methods to access and modify attributes, and observe how changes to attributes affect method behavior. Output: A script that manages Song objects with titles and artists, updates their attributes, and prints formatted descriptions of each song from instance methods.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Library system mini‑app
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply multiple classes and interacting objects to model a simple real‑world scenario, tracing how objects from different classes call each other’s methods and use attributes. Output: A small program where Book and Member objects interact to “borrow” and “return” books, printing status messages that reflect the current state of each object.

lessons.title: Constructors: where objects begin
masteryOutcomes: Understand the __init__ syntax, and the idea of a constructor
Recognize that __init__ runs automatically when an object is created.

lessons.title: Constructors with inputs
masteryOutcomes: Write an __init__ method that receives parameters and assigns them to attributes.
Instantiate objects by passing arguments to the constructor.
Understand that required constructor parameters must be provided.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: To‑do list - Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice writing a basic __init__ constructor that runs automatically, setting up default attributes when objects are created. Output: A script that creates Task objects with default attributes (like title and completed status) and prints their initial state when instantiated.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: To‑do list - Part 2
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use constructors with parameters to require input at object creation time and understand how missing or incorrect arguments affect instantiation. Output: A script that creates Task objects by passing in titles and priorities to __init__, then prints a formatted list of tasks showing each task’s details.

lessons.title: Instance attributes vs class attributes, common pitfalls
masteryOutcomes: Understand the difference between per-object state and shared class-level state.
Choose when a value should belong to the instance versus the class.

lessons.title: Keeping objects valid
masteryOutcomes: Add validation logic inside __init__.
Apply safe fallback values when constructor inputs are invalid.
Recognize validation as part of responsible object design, with real life examples.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker - Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Differentiate between instance attributes and class attributes by modeling per-user data versus shared settings, and decide where each value belongs. Output: A script that creates multiple User objects with their own step counts while sharing a class-level daily step goal, then prints summaries showing both individual progress and the common goal.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker - Part 2
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Add validation and safe fallback values inside __init__ to keep objects in a valid state when given bad input. Output: A script that creates User objects for the fitness tracker, rejecting or correcting invalid inputs (like negative age or impossible step goals) and printing validated user profiles.

lessons.title: Challenge II
masteryOutcomes: Apply constructors, attributes, and methods to solve a small end-to-end problem
Evaluate how object design choices affect program behavior

lessons.title: Review: bringing objects to life
masteryOutcomes: Consolidate understanding of how objects are created, initialized, and used over time
Identify and correct common mistakes in beginner class designs

lessons.title: Many objects, one class
masteryOutcomes: Create multiple objects from the same class with identical starting state.
Modify the state of one object without affecting the others.
Compare and interpret the state of multiple objects after different method calls.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Cafe order ticket
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice designing a class with a constructor, attributes, and methods, and observe how design choices affect multiple object instances over time. Output: A script that creates several cafe order tickets, updates each independently, and prints their final states for comparison.

lessons.title: Reading Object State
masteryOutcomes: Read and interpret the current state of an object.
Compare the state of multiple objects and explain why their values differ.
Identify which attributes changed and which remained the same during execution.

lessons.title: Modeling relationships: one-to-one and one-to-many
masteryOutcomes: Understand how to model a one-to-many relationship using objects and attributes.
Ability to decide where a relationship should be stored.
Understand how relationships affect responsibilities and state changes.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Library book tracker
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Strengthen your ability to read and compare object state across multiple instances and explain why their values differ after various operations. Output: A script that tracks several Book objects, logs the changes in their attributes as they are borrowed and returned, and prints a summary of each book’s state.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Playlist and songs
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Model one-to-one and one-to-many relationships between objects and decide where to store and update these relationships. Output: A script that manages a Playlist object containing many Song objects, allowing songs to be added, removed, and listed with their current relationships.

lessons.title: Working with lists of objects
masteryOutcomes: Iterate over a list of objects to access their data or behavior.
Call object methods while processing a collection of objects.

lessons.title: Manipulating objects in programs
masteryOutcomes: Modify object state while iterating over a list of objects.
Use object data and behavior to produce program-level results.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: To-do list manager - Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice iterating over a list of objects and calling their methods to access and display their data. Output: A script that stores multiple Task objects in a list, loops through them, and prints formatted information about each task.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: To-do list manager - Part 2
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Modify object state while iterating over a list of objects and use their data and behavior to compute program-level results. Output: A script that updates Task objects (e.g., marking done, changing priority) in a list and prints a summary including counts of completed and pending tasks.

lessons.title: Building objects from input
masteryOutcomes: Create objects using user input inside a loop.
Store created objects in a list.

lessons.title: Who owns the state?
masteryOutcomes: Understand why putting logic in the right object improves clarity and reduces bugs.
Refactor a simple interaction by moving logic to a more appropriate class.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Movie night planner - Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Create objects from user input inside a loop and store them in a list for later processing. Output: A script that repeatedly asks the user for movie details, builds Movie objects from the input, and stores them in a watchlist.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Movie night planner - Part 2
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Refactor responsibilities between classes so that logic for managing state and behavior lives in the most appropriate object. Output: A script in which the Movie or Watchlist class encapsulates logic like filtering, formatting, and selection, while the main program simply coordinates user interaction.

lessons.title: Review: when objects meet
masteryOutcomes: Review how objects collaborate through relationships and method calls
Diagnose issues in object interactions and propose improvements

lessons.title: Encapsulation: owning object state
masteryOutcomes: Understand the principle of encapsulation, as one of the core OOP principles
Use internal attributes to store object state.
Use getter methods to read object data instead of direct access.

lessons.title: Encapsulation: protecting object state
masteryOutcomes: Use setter methods to update object state.
Apply simple validation rules inside setters to prevent invalid state.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Cafe order tracker
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice designing collaborating objects with encapsulated state using getters and setters to safely manage a cafe’s orders. Output: A simple console-based cafe system that lets you create, update, and view orders while validating order data through methods instead of direct attribute access.

lessons.title: Keeping it in the family: introducing inheritance
masteryOutcomes: Understand the principle of inheritance, as one of the core OOP principles
Create a subclass that inherits attributes and methods from a parent class.
Use inherited behavior on subclass objects.

lessons.title: Inheritance: sometimes kids are not like their parents
masteryOutcomes: Override a method in a subclass to change behavior.
Predict which method implementation runs for a subclass object.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Music library inheritance
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply inheritance by creating a base MediaItem class and specialized subclasses that reuse and extend shared behavior. Output: A script that creates songs, podcasts, and audiobooks as subclasses and prints their details using inherited and customized methods.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Zoo animals behavior
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Reinforce method overriding by creating an Animal base class and multiple subclasses that change how shared methods behave. Output: A program that loops through different animal objects and calls the same methods (like speak or move) to show different subclass-specific outputs.

lessons.title: Composition vs inheritance: a practical decision rule
masteryOutcomes: Explain the difference between 'has-a' and 'is-a' relationships.
Choose composition when one object should contain or use another object as a part.
Choose inheritance when one object is a specialized version of another.

lessons.title: Polymorphism basics: one action, different behaviors
masteryOutcomes: Recognize polymorphism as a practical tool for simpler program logic.
Call the same method name on different object types and predict what happens.
Understand why method overriding enables different behavior under the same interface.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Game inventory system
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Distinguish when to use composition vs inheritance by building items that either “are-a” type of item or “have-a” component like durability or effects. Output: A game inventory script that creates various items, some composed of helper objects (e.g., Stats, Durability), and prints their combined details.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Payment processing polymorphism
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.

Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use polymorphism to simplify logic by calling the same process_payment method on different payment types and predicting their behavior. Output: A checkout script that accepts multiple payment method objects (card, PayPal, gift card) and processes them via a single unified interface.

lessons.title: Making objects readable
masteryOutcomes: Implement a simple __str__ method to produce human-friendly output.
Recognize the purpose of __repr__ at a beginner level.

lessons.title: Challenge
masteryOutcomes: Use encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism together in a small project
Summarize how advanced OOP features simplify complex logic

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Library catalog formatting
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Implement readable __str__ and basic __repr__ methods to make domain objects (like Book and Member) display clearly in logs and user messages. Output: A library catalog script that prints user-friendly summaries of books and members and shows more detailed developer-style representations when inspected.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Ride-sharing mini app – Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Combine encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism in a small ride-sharing domain model to manage drivers, riders, and trips. Output: A program that creates different user types and trips, validates their state via setters, and simulates trip requests using polymorphic behavior.

lessons.title: ⚙ Practice Lesson: Ride-sharing mini app – Part 2
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.

Exercise goals and desired output: Extend the ride-sharing model by adding readable string representations and refining polymorphic trip pricing and summaries. Output: A script that prints clear human-friendly trip summaries, shows different price calculations per ride type, and exposes helpful debug output via __repr__ for core objects.
